Mass. R. Civ. P. 1(b).proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester Superior Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 1(b) and general venue statutes because the Premises and the incident are located in Worcester County.

M.G.L. c. 260, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: This action is filed within the applicable statute of limitations. Byrne v. Rutledge, 328 Mass. 58 (1951) (.raw_text: Byrne v. Rutledge, 328 Mass. 58 (1951) (premises liability and duty to keep premises in safe condition)
Byrne v. Rutledge, 328 Mass. 58 (1951) (.proposition: Byrne v. Rutledge, 328 Mass. 58 (1951) (premises liability and duty to keep premises in safe condition)
Byrne v. Rutledge, 328 Mass. 58 (1951) (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Byrne v. Rutledge is a broker’s commission case involving contract and agency issues (whether the broker procured a ready, willing, and able lessee or purchaser, and the effect of nonjoinder of co-owners). It does not involve premises liability, landowner/occupier duties, or any duty to keep premises in a safe condition. Citing this case for a premises-liability duty rule is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Byrne v. Rutledge, 328 Mass. 58 (1951) (.relevant_excerpt: “This is an action of contract by a broker to recover a commission as alleged in the first count of his declaration for procuring a lessee and in the second count for procuring a purchaser for certain premises located in Worcester… There was, however, sufficient evidence to warrant a finding for the plaintiff upon the first.count of the declaration to recover a commission for procuring a lessee.”

Gaudette v. Framingham, 376 Mass. 246 (1.raw_text: Gaudette v. Framingham, 376 Mass. 246 (1978) (notice and defendants responsibility for dangerous conditions)
Gaudette v. Framingham, 376 Mass. 246 (1.proposition: Gaudette v. Framingham, 376 Mass. 246 (1978) (notice and defendants responsibility for dangerous conditions)
Gaudette v. Framingham, 376 Mass. 246 (1.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Gaudette v. Framingham and does not concern notice or a defendant’s responsibility for dangerous conditions. Instead, it addresses statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 90, §§ 24, 24D, and 24E regarding license revocation after conviction for operating under the influence, and related constitutional challenges. It therefore does not support the proposition about notice and responsibility for dangerous conditions.
Gaudette v. Framingham, 376 Mass. 246 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We think it appropriate to mention that there is no issue before us as to the power of a judge to allow a motion for a new trial if sufficient grounds are presented. See G. L. c. 278, § 29; c. 218, § 27A. The Commonwealth suggests, and we agree, that, after a jury verdict, trial judges are powerless to alter that verdict except by a motion for a new trial or by a motion for a directed verdict of not guilty.”

Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 2.raw_text: Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 297 (1985) (owners duty to remedy hazardous conditions)
Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 297 (1985) (owners duty to remedy hazardous conditions)
Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 2.case_name: Yerardi's Moody Street Restaurant & Lounge, Inc. v. Board of Selectmen
Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a liquor licensee’s challenge to a local board’s denial of an extension of closing hours and the scope of certiorari review, not premises liability or an owner’s duty to remedy hazardous physical conditions. The court analyzes administrative discretion, public need, hearings, and arbitrary or capricious decision-making, but does not discuss any duty of a property owner to correct or warn of dangerous conditions on land. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition about an owner’s duty to remedy hazardous conditions.
Brantley v. Ragosta, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt: “The statutory standard that governs a local authority in choosing this or that closing hour — whether as a general regulation or for a particular licensee — is ‘the public need.’ … However, the discretion lodged in the local authorities is not unlimited. These agencies may not act upon mere whim or vagary. Put another way, besides the unreviewable elements in the agency decisions, there are other elements submissible to the test of elementary justice that is invoked by the words ‘arbitrary or capricious.’”

Desrosiers v. Ensor, 429 Mass. 707 (1999.raw_text: Desrosiers v. Ensor, 429 Mass. 707 (1999) (duty and foreseeability in negligence)
Desrosiers v. Ensor, 429 Mass. 707 (1999.proposition: Desrosiers v. Ensor, 429 Mass. 707 (1999) (duty and foreseeability in negligence)
Desrosiers v. Ensor, 429 Mass. 707 (1999.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal sentencing/double jeopardy case about whether G.L. c. 94C, § 32A(d) creates a separate offense or is a sentencing enhancement, and about when an enhanced sentence may be imposed. It does not discuss civil negligence, duty, or foreseeability, nor does it articulate any general tort duty/foreseeability principles. Therefore it does not support a proposition about duty and foreseeability in negligence.
Desrosiers v. Ensor, 429 Mass. 707 (1999.relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that G. L. c. 94C, § 32A (d), is a sentencing enhancement statute that calls for a longer sentence if a violation of § 32A (c), alleged and proved, is shown to have followed a prior conviction of certain drug offenses. It does not state a separate crime. ... The Legislature did not intend that two sentences should be imposed, one for a violation of § 32A (c) and another resulting from the fact that the conviction was a second offense under § 32A (d)."

Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 395 Mass. 591 (1985) (notice, foreseeability, and duty)
Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 395 Mass. 591 (1985) (notice, foreseeability, and duty)
Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Ferragamo v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The decision clearly addresses duty and foreseeability in the negligence analysis by upholding the jury’s finding that MBTA knew or should have known of the PVC hazard, which imposed a duty to warn. The court also discusses sufficiency of evidence on causation and the foreseeability of harm from toxic fumes when the car was dismantled. However, the opinion is not a broad doctrinal treatment of "notice, foreseeability, and duty" but applies those concepts to the specific facts, so it supports that proposition in a case-specific way rather than as a general statement of law.
Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: The judge further held that although “[t]he evidence on this question is slight,” there was “enough to warrant a jury to find that PVC was present on or in the car; that this presence was known or should have been known to the defendant and imposed on the defendant a duty to warn of the danger involved in cutting up the car with an acetylene torch.” … We agree with the judge’s own observation that the evidence, although “slight,” sufficed to permit the jury to find that the decedent died as a result of exposure to toxic fumes released when he burned through PVC present on or in Car No. 3298.

McCarthy v. Anderson, 382 Mass. 54 (1980.raw_text: McCarthy v. Anderson, 382 Mass. 54 (1980) (standard of care for property owners)
McCarthy v. Anderson, 382 Mass. 54 (1980.proposition: McCarthy v. Anderson, 382 Mass. 54 (1980) (standard of care for property owners)
McCarthy v. Anderson, 382 Mass. 54 (1980.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of McCarthy v. Anderson is a dissent focused on land registration, fraud, and collateral attack on a registration decree under G.L. c. 185. It does not discuss the general standard of care for property owners (e.g., premises liability or duties to lawful entrants). Because the issue here is title registration and fraud—not the negligence standard for property owners—the case does not support the claimed proposition about a standard of care for property owners.
McCarthy v. Anderson, 382 Mass. 54 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “More important than the result in this specific case, however, is the extent to which today’s decision impairs the carefully balanced system of rights and remedies contained in the Land Registration Act as a whole. The statutory provisions and the prior decisions of this court, as well as other relevant commentary, all emphasize the preeminence of the policies of certainty and finality there embodied. Today’s recognition of ‘constructive’ or ‘technical’ fraud as an exception to those policies in my opinion represents a drastic and unwarranted inroad into the legislative scheme.”

Sullivan v. Boston Gas Co., 386 Mass. 62.raw_text: Sullivan v. Boston Gas Co., 386 Mass. 629 (1982) (causation and proximate cause)
Sullivan v. Boston Gas Co., 386 Mass. 62.proposition: Sullivan v. Boston Gas Co., 386 Mass. 629 (1982) (causation and proximate cause)
Sullivan v. Boston Gas Co., 386 Mass. 62.support_reasoning: The case directly analyzes the liability standard in defamation actions involving private plaintiffs, deciding that the negligence standard from Stone v. Essex County Newspapers applies and discussing how negligence relates to defamatory impact and inaccuracy. It also evaluates retroactivity and proximate causation-like inquiries (sufficiency of evidence of negligence causing reputational harm). Thus, it is properly cited for principles concerning causation/proximate cause in defamation under a negligence framework.
Sullivan v. Boston Gas Co., 386 Mass. 62.relevant_excerpt:
We conclude that this case is governed by the negligence standard adopted in Stone v. Essex County Newspapers, Inc., 367 Mass. 849 (1975), and the evidence is sufficient to warrant a finding of negligence. We vacate the judgment and remand the case to the Superior Court for findings as to whether Barnicle was in fact negligent.
...
We believe that if the evidence were read in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, and all questions of credibility resolved in favor of the plaintiff, the record would support a finding of negligence as to both defamatory impact and inaccuracy.

Marr v. Housing Auth. of Cambridge, 365.raw_text: Marr v. Housing Auth. of Cambridge, 365 Mass. 607 (1974) (landlord duties and notice)
Marr v. Housing Auth. of Cambridge, 365.proposition: Marr v. Housing Auth. of Cambridge, 365 Mass. 607 (1974) (landlord duties and notice)
Marr v. Housing Auth. of Cambridge, 365.support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent by Justice Quirico in a case about equitable restrictions on Back Bay property and the constitutionality of G.L. c. 184, § 30; it does not concern residential landlord-tenant duties or notice obligations. The proposition label (“landlord duties and notice”) appears mismatched to this opinion’s subject matter, so this citation does not support that proposition. Because only the dissent is provided and nothing touches landlord duties or notice, the support is absent.
Marr v. Housing Auth. of Cambridge, 365.relevant_excerpt: "General Laws c. 184, § 30, provides that no restriction shall be enforced or declared to be enforceable ‘unless it is determined... [to be] of actual and substantial benefit to a person claiming rights of enforcement.’ It further provides that even if determined to be of such benefit, a restriction shall not ‘be enforced or declared to be enforceable, except in appropriate cases by award of money damages,’ if any one of five specified sets of facts or circumstances exists."

Kuklis v. Loring (example on owner liabi.raw_text: Kuklis v. Loring (example on owner liability); see also authorities collected in SJC decisions addressing landlord/owner liability
Kuklis v. Loring (example on owner liabi.proposition: Kuklis v. Loring (example on owner liability); see also authorities collected in SJC decisions addressing landlord/owner liability

Horowitz v. Sargent, 354 Mass. 27 (1968).raw_text: Horowitz v. Sargent, 354 Mass. 27 (1968) (general negligence duty)
Horowitz v. Sargent, 354 Mass. 27 (1968).proposition: Horowitz v. Sargent, 354 Mass. 27 (1968) (general negligence duty)
Horowitz v. Sargent, 354 Mass. 27 (1968).support_reasoning: The opinion is a probate case dealing with domicile, sufficiency of notice to heirs, standards for revoking a decree allowing a will, and the probate court’s discretionary power to reopen default decrees. It does use negligence terminology (e.g., ‘grossly negligent’ and ‘did not exercise due diligence’), but only in applying a due‑diligence standard to notice, not in articulating any general negligence duty rule. It therefore does not stand as authority for a broad “general negligence duty” proposition.
Horowitz v. Sargent, 354 Mass. 27 (1968).relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly the judge was justified in deciding, as he did, that Bowen, in his failure to get a notice to Mrs. Reed, ‘did not exercise due diligence.’ Upon the evidence, the failure seems to us grossly negligent.”

Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause and foreseeability principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..proposition: Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause and foreseeability principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..support_reasoning: The opinion is the classic source for the modern American formulation of duty and proximate cause in terms of foreseeability. Cardozo grounds liability on whether the defendant’s conduct created a reasonably foreseeable risk of harm to the particular plaintiff, rejecting liability where injury was outside the “range of apprehension.” Thus the case directly supports the proposition that Palsgraf stands for proximate cause and foreseeability principles.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional… The range of reasonable apprehension is at times a question for the court, and at times, if varying inferences are possible, a question for the jury.”

MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..raw_text: MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y. 382 (1916) (duty to those foreseeably injured)
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..proposition: MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y. 382 (1916) (duty to those foreseeably injured)
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..support_reasoning: MacPherson v. Buick is the landmark case that rejects the strict privity limitation and holds that a manufacturer of a product owes a duty of care to persons who may foreseeably be injured by its negligent manufacture, even if they are not in contractual privity. Although the provided text is the dissent, the overall case holding (as reflected in the judgment of affirmance and Cardozo’s majority, not fully reproduced here) is precisely that Buick owed a duty to the subvendee/user foreseeably endangered by its negligence. Thus, the case is correctly cited for the duty to those foreseeably injured.
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: The theory upon which the case was submitted to the jury... was that, although an automobile is not an inherently dangerous vehicle, it may become such if equipped with a weak wheel; and "that if the motor car in question, when it was put upon the market was in itself inherently dangerous by reason of its being equipped with a weak wheel, the defendant was chargeable with a knowledge of the defect so far as it might be discovered by a reasonable inspection and the application of reasonable tests. This liability... was not limited to the original vendee, but extended to a subvendee like the plaintiff..."
